positive.review:
Pro's and Cons

Pros: It's fun to play, pretty, and the open world dungeons are really neat. The enemy variety in game is great. Bosses and PVE content seem well designed. Loads of stuff to waste time on PVE wise. 

EVERYTHING is voiced over. The stories are... largely forgettable - but fun to follow along with nonetheless. World bosses, hidden areas, and a good amount of content, it has a lot going for it. 

Recently, they added a "Path of Ascension", which get's players pretty yoked (6000GS) by the end of it. This takes a lot of the grind out of the game, which is nice. Makes it fun. 

Castle Sieges are fun as hell if you're geared, It's like the entire server vs 1 guild, vs eachother and things get hectic. There really is no other pvp like it. 

Okay, so now that I've made the game sound like Emma Watson with D cups, let's get into the fact she doesn't shower, sleeps with people for money, and has a raging case of the clap. 

Cons: *deep breath* It can feel very buggy at times, Especially some of the jumping/morph/grappling hook things. When you get a few dozen players together, shit just performs poorly. 

This in and of itself would be forgivable - buuuuuut the auction house is a paid feature and this is where the cracks really show up. 

The player trading/Auction house is entirely handled in Lucent - the games premium in game currency. It costs Lucent to list something, and there's not really a way to "earn" free Lucent. - meaning you need to spend money, in some amount - to even use it; and as a byproduct, the game is HEAVILY pay to win. 

Everything on the Auction house is an in game drop, so it's not as direct as  "Buy item from shop". There's an element of scarcity that comes with items being rare and ultra rare drops. And it is a money sink. Some of the weapons on this game cost literal thousands of dollars. 

Don't bullshit yourself thinking you can do it all for free - the game is designed to make that more or less impossible. There is a limit to drops you can farm in certain areas, a limit to the amount of drops you can claim in dungeons, a limit to how many things you can do to advance your character for free. 

Read: Even if you are an unemployed basement dweller, you can't just grind to get to the top. 

So, all of the above makes PvP a battle of who has the deepest pockets.  Imagine if having a higher spec PC equated to having more skill. It's literally that. Guy who dropped 10k on his character is an un-killable god and you are going to get dumpstered unless you have spent somewhere in the 4 figure range on your account. 

Which is disappointing - as if they made the game LESS pay to win I could see them potentially drawing more players and making more money.

So all in all - should you play it? 

 Right now we are in an MMO drought. With New Worlds impending death, I don't know if there is another MMO with an active PvP community. PvE wise I think it's worth a shot just to try something different than WoW and FFXIV. 

If you want to do PvE? Sure. I can recommend it. Just play casually and don't get caught up in the hype and drop money - Amazon may kill this one next. 

If you want to engage in PvP? Eeeehhhhh. If you have deep pockets, go for it.

I like it, but I'm starting to get bored with it and it is turning into a grind.  They upped the character levels, which is good for power but they've also added more gear at Epic II and Epic III, plus "Legendary".  That turns the game into an expensive and frustrating ordeal in order to keep up...aka, not fun.      They've also added a home residence that you can decorate, but getting the mats is a huge grind.   Frankly, I don't even bother going to the residence anymore.  Waste of time.

Besides all its flaws with its bugs, the pay to progress aspect and the bad RNG I really enjoy TL. I feel like the devs put a lot of love and effort into this game, even with it being quite buggy, but they listen to the community a lot. Yes, there is some repetitive daily grind, but I feel like this is just a general MMORPG thing. Also, keep in mind this game is one year old. That's not much for an MMORPG. The upcoming content looks really promising and the recently added housing and achievement system are fun  activities for when you just want to chill a bit, decorate, craft or try to get certain achievements.

I wouldn't personally play this as a PvP game, because if you don't have a PvP build besides your PvE build, which is quite expensive in ressources and time, you won't get far. Everytime I try PvP I just get oneshot, so I just don't bother and I don't really feel like I'm missing much. I just wish there was a way to casually participate in the serverwide PvP events like castle siege without having to be in a PvP guild with all maxed out gear.

This game is hands down the BEST MMO ive ever played. ESO doesnt even come close to how amazing this game is. I've always wanted to get into MMOs but ESO and a few others ruined it for me. I saw the trailer for this game and figured i'd give it a go, its free why not. To my surprise this game is a 10/10. I would pay 70$ for this title.

Minor Complaints:
There are a few optimization issues, i have a Ryzen 7 7800x3D and a 3080. I should have no issues running this game at max settings and getting at least 120 FPS. However there are many areas where my FPS drops to 40-50 and its quite annoying.

This game allows the use of controllers and thats fantastic! however the UI is a bit hard to use on controller, for example to claim rewards you have to hold Y and then use the D pad to select where you want to go. Hit A and then you have to manually scroll through all of the areas with the D pad to collect what you want, the game should definitely add a cursor for controller in the pause menu/after holding Y.

The trailer makes this game look epic, massive fights, large classes of magic, numerous weapons and armor sets, and magic specific to your class (or magic type/symbol). It doesnt seem the game really explains the symbols and different kinds of magic, and so far (level 35) im unable to see what the different classes bring to the table. It all seems the same. On top of that the game needs way more epic fights and richer lore for each area. Starting out you just kinda do random missions and touch stones for the game to be like "This place used to be cool till a mean wizard casted a naughty spell and now everyone is flowers, and theyre hungry" whoever wrote that bit took inspiration from their child and is holding onto it for dear life throughout the game. Boss fights are sort of cool but i would like to see more elemental things happening, make the grim reaper summon Draugr and demons, make him summon a shadow beast or something. Make the fights more like Elden-Borne-Souls.

There is a battlepass, please remove it. Its stupid. No one likes it. There are also pay for skin/weapons/armor options, please remove that as well. Instead hide legendary skins and loot all over the world and make players search for it. Add a massive underwater side to the map, even underground and in the sky. Easily tons more content and hiding places.

Positives:
The game has a sprint option (thank god) and instead of sprinting you turn into a Jaguar, Lion, Bird, skins vary. Each one has its own cool skin and unique speed. Truly a beautiful way of doing it.
Armor sets are very beautiful and the graphics for this game are PERFECT. I would like to see a large increase in saturation/HDR content for the spells, i want the fire to look like its coming through my screen. Still, 10/10

Summary:
For a free to play game, this is absolutely the most perfect and (in my opinion) the only good MMO out there. The things listed above are only minor and if all of them are corrected this game would be a AAA game worth 50-70$ per copy.

E N G L I S H  /    /  S P A N I S H

Throne & Liberty feels like a confused mix of MMO ideas that never fully come together. The game systems are unnecessarily fragmented, with progression split across weapon levels, traits, litography, codex entries, enchantments, and multiple currencies. None of it is explained well, making the early game feel like a chore instead of a learning curve.
Combat is functional but lacks depth, and the game heavily pushes you into group play. If you prefer playing solo, you will quickly fall behind. Even basic progression feels slow unless you join a guild or spend money on boosts. The game clearly leans toward a pay-to-progress model, even if not outright pay-to-win.
UI and menus are overcrowded, unintuitive, and often feel like they were designed without considering new players. Important features are buried under layers of tabs and submenus.
Overall, the game looks good and has potential, but the experience is frustrating, overwhelming, and unfriendly to anyone who is not already familiar with modern Korean MMO design. If you‚Äôre coming from classic RPGs or older MMOs, expect a steep and unpleasant adjustment.

üí¨ Hours played: 126

Throne and Liberty honestly surprised me in the best way. The world is gorgeous ‚Äî every area feels alive, from the weather shifts to the lighting and creature designs. You can glide, climb, and even transform to explore, and it all just flows together really smoothly.

Combat feels great once you get into it. It‚Äôs fast, flexible, and lets you mix up your playstyle by swapping weapons on the fly. Whether you‚Äôre running dungeons, exploring solo, or joining massive PvP battles, there‚Äôs always something going on.

Speaking of PvP ‚Äî those large-scale fights are insane (in a good way). The sieges and world events feel epic, and when your guild actually pulls off a win, it‚Äôs incredibly rewarding.

Performance can dip a bit during big fights, and there‚Äôs still some balancing to be done, but overall the game‚Äôs in a solid place. You can tell the devs are actively improving things, which gives me a lot of confidence for the future.

If you‚Äôre into MMOs with stunning visuals, smooth combat, and massive battles that actually feel meaningful, Throne and Liberty is absolutely worth checking out.

‚≠ê 9/10 ‚Äì Beautiful world, great combat, and huge potential.

The story and lore is nice if you enjoy that aspect of gaming, as well as, the leveling, PvP, PvE, solo and group instances. This game had potential, but there are far too many negatives to give this a positive review.
Firstly, it's buggy & laggy (at times, but those times are often). The updates are not well tested and often break parts of the game, usually not fixed for several days and resulting in additional downtime (I am writing this during another one of those times - the 3rd time this week).
The play limitations are very annoying (and are made to maintain value of their premium currency); there are a few specific ways to move forward with your character progression, all of which are limited by several in game tokens/currencies which refresh slowly over the course of a week. To give an example of how this works: Do you want to get new gear (or traits for your gear)? Do a dungeon, but you can only get rewards once per day (with the refresh cycle of tokens). Do you want to level up your gear or mastery? Do open world dungeons, which require tokens primarily granted from dungeons, and have a limited time you actually get rewards from it. It prevents people from playing too much and deprives them of the choice of how spend their time in game, all to mitigate impact to their monetization strategy.
Now their premium currency (lucent).. that's interesting. Everything you want to buy or sell is done using their premium currency (which means you can pay to win) - however, you're limited to how much you can earn. I'll explain with another example: want to make lucent? Sell items/traits. Want to sell items/traits? Use trait unlock stones. Want trait unlockstones? You can only buy a certain amount by week with another currency gained by doing quests. Also, you can only completed limited quests per day (5).
Essentially, the game is an interconnected web of grinding that is purposely made slow by the developers with small incremental impacts to your characters power. 
Pay for Convenience is a little annoying. Spend about a week grinding lucent to buy Davinci Blessing, and for the next 4 weeks you can spend your activity tokens (e.g. dungeons, open world dungeons, quests) twice as fast.
Same idea with Battle Passes, it's about 1 week worth of lucent grind to get a 30 day battle pass that grants you rewards that are so useful you can't "not" buy it. Then you need to do several side-quests daily & weekly, forcing you to engage in content that you may not enjoy, like Fishing/Cooking.
Oh yeah, there are weekly rewards that require you to engage with different kinds of content. For this weekly reward and battle pass, if you go to the Lawless Isle (Nebula Island) and step off the portal platform, you'll find a dozen players afking to get their obligatory 2-4 hours spent in that zone to complete the weekly/battle pass quest.

Now some positive elements (I mean, there must be some if I played for several hundred hours.. right?).
The combat, abilities, creating builds - it's fun. They have built in systems like Item Sync to allow you to play around with different equipment builds. You can move your class/skill & ability progression to another by using vouchers earned from Battle Passes (albeit not often).
I'm not a fan of PvP in this game, it's very "rock/paper/scissors" with very little balance. Example: the "meta" is critical damage, so the counter is stacking Endurance & % critical damage reduction. Or one ranged class is dominating in PvP, so people counter by stacking Ranged Evasion to mitigate the hits the land. It's not skill, it's luck & "strategic engagement" (if that were really possible).
Dungeons are decent, however there is a lot of unecessary "puzzle" mechanics during the boss fights. Example: arena gets divided into purple/yellow colors, players can't move across the border or they get damaged constantly. The boss throws a ball at one side, a player has to "catch" the ball while facing the opposite colors side and "throw" the ball for a player on the opposite side to "catch". Then they get a magic tether which they have keep lined up on the boss to break their shield, otherwise the mechanic might insta-kill the group. It's adding complexity for it's own sake, rather than difficulty or making engaging content.

I digress... if you've read this and feel like you'll enjoy the game, check it out. There is some fun to be had, it is a bit addictive - but it is also frustrating.. often.
I guess I'll check if they've fixed the issues causing downtime on a Friday evening, but I doubt it.
Cheers

347 hours of wasted time... maybe 10 of this was afk total, over a period of about 3 months, and maybe a little less. Well over 10 full days of my life playing this game. Just deleted at right about 7000 combat power.

Recently the Auction house got nuked because of the incompetence of the support staff, they literally gave out millions of premium currency to a guild that requested the standard free, currency called Sollent after not getting it from some Siege event that bugged. Of course this guild turns around and buys out just about everything in the auctionhouse in a free for all that basically destroys the market and shuts down the game for 12 hours while they "fix" the problem. They bring it up about 12 hours later, as I said, and the problems aren't even solved, seemed like noone who exploited the issue got banned, and many, many people who weren't even involved in the guild came on to having NEGATIVE lucent (The premium currency). 

This is only the most RECENT in a LONG line of incompetent bugs and glitches that I've noticed in the relatively short time I've played this game in comparison to the toxic players who've played the game since it's inception last year, which brings me to another point. 

The playerbase. The playerbase is one of the most toxic I've ever seen in any MMORPG, and I've logged over 5000 hours between FFXIV and WOW. The PVP is total ass, there's NO balance whatsoever, the formula is literally, you spend enough money and have the time to sit on your ass all day and play this silly game, and you smash everyone. No combat power caps for pvp events like Battlegrounds, no real skill involved, just one-shotting the f2p people who play the hell out of the game in hopes of getting a drop at a worldboss or archboss that realistically only ever consistently rewards the whales and those who've spend thousands of hours grinding up there equipment, and AGS just rakes in the cash and continues to be incompetent. The game just went through a major update about a month ago too, and put through a bunch of so called "hyperboost" and a "path of ascension" feature that's designed to build you from 0-55 and about 6000 combat power in a few short days with the idea of catching people up and getting them into relevant content.

However, regardless, the game is extremely PVP centric. All major events that really reward the most, are PVP, and good luck going into pvp with their measly so called hyperboost or path of ascension. You may think you've done something with yourself and be psyched to get into the battlegrounds, then you're faced with the reality of being near instantly oneshotted by some sweaty nerd who plays the game all day every day AND drops 100s if not 1000s of dollars into it, and it doesn't change. Not unless you give in and spend the money yourself, and even then, you'll still probably get smashed over and over by the people who've played daily for a year BECAUSE THERE'S NO REAL BALANCE. There's little skill involved at all. If you have the gear you win. Pretty simple. 

The PVE is repetitive and the rewards are a pittance compared to the PVP garbage.
Want a top 10 guild? Better be prepared to build your character the way THEY want, you better be willing to be a sweaty no life nerd like them too, PVE? Good luck. You'll be lucky if they do the guild bosses at the same time every week, but that's unlikely, because they'll likely push it back for some crap pvp event where they aren't even competitive in and just waste everyone's time.

Spent about 3k hours playing that, though I prolly afked for about 20% of it. Overall the concept of the game that was present in t1 and later in t2 is enjoyable for those who prefer PvP, like myself. From world bosses to boon/rift wars between guilds to then wargames and sieges - everything felt like an old school MMORPG. The devs took out some things from the legendary L2 but made it more casual-friendly, and less engaging overall. Now i'll just list some pros and cons, and explain what went wrong with game direction in my humble opinion.   I've had a lot of experience with the game, been top50 arena multiple times since the release in Europe, and who knows how many hours I've spent in meaningless PvP dances around world bosses.

Pros:
+ Open world PvP used to be actually old-school. OwPvP bosses felt very fun in zergy fights, since guilds could form 4-side alliance; was quite nostalgic especially at the start when there were a lot of sides on each server. Later devs felt it was too hardcore and only left 2 OW archbosses a week to fight over, others bosses became GvG-like which essentially made it worse for smaller guilds because they didnt have enough meta classes nor skill to compete in fair battles(there is always a bigger fish). All they had to do was to reduce alliances to 2 guilds(which they did a year later, when it was too late).

+ Optimization. I managed to enjoy zerg fights and epic sieges with epic number of characters and somewhat mid graph settings, while having RTX 4060 and I5 12th gen. That's pretty impressive, people with high-end PCs had no problem rendering 300+ players on the screen with stable 50-60 fps(w/ DLSS ofc). Overall it's been improving since the release.
+ Guild-based content, the game offered a lot of advantages for PvP-oriented guilds and had enough to keep people engaged. Boon/rift fights, sieges then later wargames is what a proper PvP mmorpg should aim to have at the very least.

+ Gear progression. Its been pretty basic(traiting and enchanting is as basic and easy as it gets), though they did make it a bit more complicated with the release of heroic gear, but it's still not that grindy and overall they've been making it less grindy since 2 month after release(giving top gear basically for free at some point of t1, then the same thing happened in t2, they've been already giving a lot of stuff for players to catch up in t3, give it another 2 months they will give out top heroic traits for free). The runes/masteries/artifacts are also friendly. That easiness does ruin economy, which ill discuss in Cons section.

Cons.
The cons of this game come from the lack of game direction. It seems like devs have always been confused about what TnL should look like.

- With the focus on Hardcore PvP and guilds they haven't offered alternatives to other players. PvE has always been pretty boring in the game, and it has never offered options to even grind it instead of PvP. Neither casual players nor hardcore PvE enjoyers could enjoy the game as there was no content for them. Not much to explore for casuals, the world feels dull, and only 1 raid. It took them more than a year to add 1 raid. And by the looks of it TnL will never see anything better.

- Lack of content quickly hit the PvP base as well. When you make engaging PvP content that can eat up a good amount of time players will expect some meaning to it, which usually includes nice rewards. But outside of Archboss PvP everything else in the game gives you nothing of value, it's been like that for a year, some value appears at the release of new tier of gear, but it quickly becomes almost free, because the devs have no idea what they are doing. On top of that, they'd released a raid instead of PvP content this summer. Only recently we saw the new BG.

- Top Loot system is too RNG. The loot is a classic casino situation for both PvP and PvE.. Even if you are in a strong hardcore guild you might not see a good(archboss) loot for weeks, if not months. As there have been a need to keep 4 active guilds and loot was shared between them(not much of it). Later as servers were quickly dying some guilds managed to simply channel the loot by afk killing empty bosses on dead servers, which resulted in most of the Archboss loot channeled to ~200 players on each server, then only those players would have access to it. That was a final verdict for the game. Alliances should've been reduced long time ago. Now with 90% servers being dead and in the need of another long-awaited server merge it doesnt really matter if you've gotten 1 or 2 guilds. The same circle-jerk of loot, with 90% of playerbase hoping to get some luck with PvE bosses, w/ obviously much lower chances.

 In the end,It took them too long to reduce alliances to 2 guilds. The cons above resulted in the lack of rewards for PvP and PvE in general. 

- You want your hardcore no-life guild to get something out of the fighting for the sakes of fighting? Well bad luck, global skill for top1 killing ranking that enabled PvP in open world dungeons was made useless - the only shiny thing that PvP players could get in that game was quickly reduced to just a number because the devs couldnt make up their mind on whether the game is PvP or afk macro another useless ow boss that dies in a second and gives you about nothing on average(unless you are lucky in the first 3-4 weeks when it costs something before they nuke it). Archboss PvP has been about the only thing to give you anything, but even then it wasnt designed to be that predatory. But because there are no other meaningful rewards Hardcore playerbase chose to simply exploit the existing system by turning servers into sleeping fest to at least get something. As for PvX guilds there isn't nothing to do either. Your leveling of the guild doesnt matter, some new guild bosses? Loot is devalued, so who rly needs it?

You want something out of wargames?(a really cool mode for custom interserver GvGs) well no luck here as well; it's been a year since they added wargames, community managed to host even 2 tournaments between guilds using this mode and guess what? They haven't come up with any logical successor of this mode, it's still just a custom mode, it gives nothing. It's just some entertainment for PvP guilds, but no serious MMORPG can last long when your most popular guild content is a custom no-reward training mode. 

- Boon/Rift wars? A nice concept, however neither buffs nor boss loot are useful. Nobody plays it anymore. A siege? Its fun but guess what? :)

- Your Arena rank? It doesnt matter I'd been top50 multiple times in Europe the rewards were a joke. Sure S2 gave you some nice nebula boxes with guaranteed loot, but it lost value in a month anyway. Now it's better, but still too little too late. Oh and they removed 3v3 arena, added a copycat of 6v6(like why, NC?). Dont get me started w/ Nebula Island; a fine concept but time-gated...

Now dont get me wrong, I am all for guilds-content and as many PvP modes as one can have. Ive myself played in mostly sweaty hardcore guilds and gotten over 100k worth lucent of loot, including several archboss weapons(about >$2000 worth). But had I not played in such guild that always aimed to dominate server and win I would have never gotten that expensive gear without swiping. There is no meaningful way to grind lots of lucent outside the first month of new gear release, NONE. You want to grind craft? Well it's useless and system feels mobile. Hence, that time window at release of new gear tiers is all you have, e.g. t3 is already "nuked", it's gonna be Groundhog day again when they add more... Good things that came in the end were the new Battleground(took 1 year to add) and nice people I've met along the way.

In conclusion, it's not worth it if you are new. And it's not about burning out, its about NCSoft sacrificing TnL in the name of their next "big thing" (Aion 2). The concept was good though.

Throne and Liberty: A Promising MMO Undermined by Lockouts and Pay-to-Win Tactics

Throne and Liberty begins with a captivating premise, boasting an immersive world, compelling lore, and thrilling combat. However, this promising foundation is severely hampered by irritating mechanics, particularly lockouts and pay-to-win (P2W) elements, which detract from the authentic MMO experience players crave.

The game initially lures players with a world brimming with adventure. The combat is dynamic, and the expansive world offers ample opportunities for exploration, quests, and group activities. The game's potential is undoubtedly enticing.

However, beneath the surface, it becomes clear that the game is engineered to encourage spending over genuine gameplay. Lockouts, which restrict content access on a daily or weekly basis, are a significant issue. It's frustrating to encounter a barrier after a few hours of play, realizing that further progress or access to certain features requires waiting for reset timers or, worse, paying to bypass the wait. This artificially extends playtime and constrains the enjoyment within a session.

The pay-to-win (P2W) mechanics further exacerbate this issue. While MMOs typically offer microtransactions for cosmetic items, Throne and Liberty goes a step further by providing powerful in-game advantages for a price. From paying to skip timers to purchasing top-tier gear, it's evident that the game prioritizes player spending over their time. This imbalance favors paying players, leaving those who opt not to spend at a severe disadvantage, unable to compete with those who invest money for advantages.

Perhaps most disappointing is that Throne and Liberty feels more like a monetization scheme than a game. Instead of creating engaging content that rewards skill, strategy, and player investment, the game forces players into a cycle of either paying to skip tedious tasks or being locked out of progress.

In summary, Throne and Liberty has the potential to be a great MMO, but its focus on lockouts and pay-to-win mechanics ultimately undermines this potential. For players who value fair play, skill-based progression, and a sense of achievement, this game will be a source of frustration. Unfortunately, it appears that the developers prioritize monetization over delivering a quality, player-first MMORPG experience.

A Player‚Äôs Opinion for Players ‚Äì Thrones and Liberty

Thrones and Liberty is a fascinating game full of promise, carried by breathtaking environments, a polished artistic direction, and an absolutely incredible soundtrack that elevates every zone and greatly enhances immersion. The gameplay mechanics are enjoyable to handle, and while the story isn‚Äôt groundbreaking, it remains coherent overall. On paper, it‚Äôs an MMORPG that truly makes you want to dive deep into its world.

From the very first hours, you‚Äôre struck by the vastness of the map and the variety of dungeons, crypts, and zones shifting between PvE and PvP. The experience is dynamic and engaging at first, though the gameplay loop unfortunately becomes repetitive over time. Thankfully, the presence of numerous diverse guilds helps keep things fresh: you can choose to play casually with friends or commit to hardcore groups where ‚ÄúIRL first‚Äù quickly gets pushed aside.

However, despite its undeniable strengths, Thrones and Liberty suffers from several major issues. Castle captures completed without fighting through exploit abuse, an unusually high level of toxicity, hundreds of bots and cheaters pulling off ‚Äúlegendary parries‚Äù in PvP, and questionable class balance all weigh heavily on the overall experience.

To make matters worse, the business model leans dangerously toward pay-to-win, creating unfair progression gaps and discouraging players who simply want to advance at their own pace without reaching for their wallet. The situation has degraded to the point where, a year after launch, players practically have to queue as tanks if they want to access group content‚Äîbecause no one plays the role anymore. Meanwhile, healers like myself now wait over an hour just to enter a dungeon instance.

It‚Äôs particularly disappointing because I‚Äôve spent nearly 1,000 hours in the game with friends and genuinely had great moments‚Äîthough far fewer than some veterans. Thrones and Liberty had everything it needed to aim for a solid 10/10, but today, it struggles to reach more than a 3.5/10.
